_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan
Executive Summary
Gavilon Fertilizer LLC
Victoria, TX.

I.    The Facility Policy:

The Facility's owner, management, and employees of Gavilon Fertilizer LLC. are 
committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia.  Local 
responders are encouraged to visit the Facility to gain firsthand knowledge of the site. Employees are required to hold monthly safety meetings. Additional training is conducted on various sections of the facility??A?s Process Safety Management plan. The Facility has prepared an internal written emergency action plan which includes ammonia releases.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with local fire departments, and authorities to mitigate any release, and to minimize the impact of a release on the population and environment.

II.   Facility Information:

The primary activity of the Facility is to manufacture and distribute agricultural fertilizer for the farming industry. Ammonia is received, stored, and used for production of  liquid fertilizer solutions and is an important source of nitrogen for local agricultural crops.
 
The maximum quantity that can be stored in the facility's stationary storage tank is 130,000 pounds. The Facility may receive ammonia in rail cars for use in polyphosphate fertilizer production.  It is not a practice to hold the car(s) any longer than is necessary. The more typical method of receiving ammonia is by truck transport containing 40,000 pounds of ammonia. The process is considered a batch process and operates intermittently.

III.  Accidental Release Prevention:
   
The Facility takes guidance from material published by the American National Standards Institute "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia" 
K61.1, and Compressed Gas Association CGA G-2.  The Facility also has a Process 
Safety  Management Program that dovetails with the RMP. It is Management's practice to minimize the amount of ammonia hel

d or stored at the facility. The Facility continues to review and look for means to improve operations, implement Best Management 
Practices, and increase safety. The Facility is also regulated by State ammonia regulations.

IV. The Five Year Accident History:
       
The facility has had no releases of ammonia pertaining to the operation in the past five years.  There have been no deaths or significant property damage at the Facility.  To the best of our knowledge, no off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage,orinvironmental damage has occurred due to the operation of this facility.



Bibliography / References:

U.S. Environmental Protection Agency  "Chemical Emergency Preparedness and 
Prevention Advisory  Ammonia", September 1991 Oswer 91-008.2, Series 8; No.2.

OHSA 40 CFR Part 68 and Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions 29 CFR Part 1910.111

American National Standard Institute, Inc., "American National Standard Safety 
Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia"  (K-61.1) March 
1989

Gavilon Fertilizer LLC. 
Kyle Nohavitza

Victoria, TX 77905
